I don't know what source you would consider authoritative, Nick, but Article I, Section 5 of the Constitution of these United States declares that "the Yeas and Nays of the Members ... on any question" shall be obtained "at the Desire of one fifth of those present."

In practice, when something is up for vote, a Member says, "Mister/Madam Speaker/President, I ask for the Yeas and NAYs". Then the person in the presiding officer's chair says something and a bunch of other people grumble and it is declared that one-fifth of those present want the Yeas and NAYs; or in other words, an [oral vote]. Then the presiding officer says that the clerk shall call the roll and those in favor are to answer by saying "Yea" while those opposed answer by saying "No". "NAY" is a term for a negative [oral vote]; it doesn't have to be the thing that the voter says to indicate opposition. The word for a sound is sometimes onomatopoetic -- meow -- and sometimes not: cry.

If someone pulls up a transcript of a congressional proceeding and disprove me on the basic facts, I'll not argue further. (Not a transcript of a Senate trial to remove a President though; there, the Democrats say "Not Guilty" and the Republicans say "Guilty", "Not Guilty", or "Not Proven".)

The easier way to know the clue is OK is that Fact Boy didn't contribute a correction.

How silly it is to say that a government should never run a deficit or surplus.  An explicit mission of our government is to "promote the general welfare." We do this via public investment in infrastructure, education, research, and countless other ways.  And the nature of investment is that you put money out and you hope to get money back. What makes government different from corporations is, rather, its mission to promote the general welfare of the nation instead of pursuing (as corporations generally do) a "beggar thy neighbor" policy designed to concentrate wealth in the hands of the few at the expense of the many.  Robbing Peter to pay Paul is a bizarrely inept description of what our government does, unless perhaps "Paul" refers to the super-rich who continue to receive massive government funding thanks to the GOP.

@jas2200 - The President is a special case.  He has a huge mansion, and huge staff, and Air Force One at his disposal - and he doesn't pay income tax on the imputed value of any of this.   He doesn't need to spend any of his income if he doesn't want to, as everything is provided.  The value of his compensation, then, is much greater than his nominal salary.

Brooklyn: I personally don't see anything wrong with the president getting a good pension. After all, it is, quite literally, one of the hardest, most stressful jobs in the world. (Ever notice how every president seems to age dramatically while in office?) And $191,000 a year pales in comparison to what many ex-legislators pull in once they leave office and find a comfy think tank, lobbyist or Wall Street position.

Instead of begrudging a former president his pension, the real question should be: Why don't working Americans have good pensions anymore? What happened to company pensions? Who came up with the IRA schemes that have benefited Wall Street much more than workers?
Just how do they get wealthy, then? I recall one university extension agent remarking that these days it takes a whole lot more poor people to make one millionaire than it used to...

The rich do not get rich at the expense of everyone else. There's not a shred of evidence that the people who, for example, founded Microsoft got rich by exploiting others.
What is true is that the tax "code" is a joke riddled with loopholes for everyone. The only rational tax code is one with graduated brackets and no deductions. Not only is that the fairest possible code, it would allow congress to actually tune the rates to balance or unbalance the budget. Imagine all those tax lawyers actually put out of work and being available to provide useful legal help to those who actually need it.

No, the 1993 Clinton tax increase was not the largest in U.S. history, neither in actual dollars or constant dollars.

In actual (raw) dollars, the Affordable Care Act was the largest tax increase in U.S. history ($76.8 billion in its largest single year, vs. $65.9 billion for the 1993 Clinton increase).
In constant (inflation adjusted) cost, Ronald Reagan's 1982 tax increase tops the list at $85.3 billion in its largest single year, vs. $80 billion for the 1993 Clinton increase.

I notice you also fail to mention the usual claim put forward by conservatives to try and minimize the success of the Clinton tax increases in balancing the nation's budget, by claiming it was all somehow the result of the tech industry bubble.

But the simple reality is, the tax increases of 1993 created the surplus that balanced our nation's deficits, giving us a surplus for several years. The only surplus, I'd point out, of my lifetime (and Truman was President when I was born). Then, of course, we got the Bush tax cuts which wiped out the surpluses we were using to eliminate that debt conservatives pretend to hate (but only when a Democrat is in the White House; otherwise, as VP Cheney famously stated, "Reagan proved deficits don't matter"), and in fact gave us the 2nd worst growth in national debt since WW2 (Reagan having given us the the largest growth in debt, a 300% increase in 8 years).

It is difficult to understand the change in effective rates for the wealthy based solely on information in this article and yesterday's article.  There are so many moving parts to the economy and our tax system that it is easy to oversimplify.  For example, the financial situation for a doctor making $2 million a year - someone in the 1% - is completely different than an entrepreneur whose stock holding appreciates by $2 million.  The doctor will be paying a lot of tax and the entrepreneur will not.  There are no bad guys in that example.  No matter what tax law is enacted, it is very difficult to define income to apply to everyone equally.  Warren Buffett owns billions of Berkshire Hathaway that pays no dividends.  Thus he pays no tax on his holdings.  Should he be taxed on the increase in the value of his holdings?  And then be refunded when his holdings decrease?  There are so many cases where there is no easy answer.

I think this issue is much more complex than most commenters are willing to acknowledge. I am pretty liberal, and obviously, I find this kind of behavior to be pretty distasteful. That being said, I think it's important in these situations to put oneself in the shoes of another. In other words, there is no controversy over whether those profiled in this story made their money in a way that was legal (Steve Cohen, not withstanding, who is in a category of his own when it comes to these things). Furthermore, they have used legal (albeit abusive, based on any standard) methods to minimize their tax bills. In other words, this is not a moral issue, but a policy issue.

I don't think any of these people are going to be persuaded that their unbridled greed is socially reprehensible, or even misguided. Thus, the goal should not be to shame them (which is clearly counter-productive), but to make sure that their investing behaviors accord with macroeconomic and macro-societal goals, and that they are compelled to pay their fair share in taxes.

Obviously, this is complicated by the fact that these same individuals are in a unique position to influence these very rules, a realization that unfortunately engenders a sense of hopelessness...

Don't be shocked, it's par for the course. Why do you think so much money flows through political campaigns? It's by wielding the power to tax and regulate that politicians can extort campaign contributions from wealthy contributors, and use the complexity of the tax code to obscure these tax-avoidance activities and make them inaccessible to us in the middle class.

The lower class get Earned Income Tax Credits and welfare benefits, the wealthy buy tax breaks from the politicians, and the middle class is left with the bill. And the attitude that lower taxes are taking away something from the government assumes it was theirs to begin with. It's not, it's our hard-earned money. The solution is to reduce taxes to the point where these schemes are no longer worthwhile, reduce the size and power of government so that's it's no longer useful to buy the politicians, and let us use our own money as we see fit, not as the politicians want to use it.

The rich didn't earn their wealth all by themselves. They built wealth using the transport and communication systems built or regulated by the government, they hire workers educated in public schools, they rely on financial systems regulated by government, they enjoy health because the government safeguards their food, water and environment and funds research to cure their diseases... the list goes on and on. If they believe they can do it all without a strong, well-financed government, they can move to Somalia or another failed state.

So often the people we send to Congress are turned by money and perks provided by lobbyists. They fool the electorate by persuading the electorate they are somehow protecting american values. It's not the tax code. It's greed and power.

He didn't pay a million in taxes, it was something like 30k in taxes - on assets (two houses) that were assessed at over 1 million - which triggered the inheritance tax in California at the time. His entire savings (around 30k) had to be used to pay the inheritance tax and that left his children struggling to do things like pay property taxes, funeral expenses, etc. I realize the inheritance tax (estate tax exemption) is now 5 million and this should help avoid the problem that happened to our family.
Still, in our family situation, the inheritance tax kicked in and our family is mostly working class. All the men worked blue-collar labor jobs and I am the only one so far who graduated from college, with lots of college debt... We are a far cry from the "nations wealthiest"...
